description: depicts the priest Ikkyu (hoisting his loincloth) and the courtesan Jigoku; at L is a hunched old man holding a white cloth aloft with a bamboo stick; at R is a woman with elaborate hairstyle and kimono with small child peeking from behind; blue and white striped cloud at TR containing several columns of writing; black rectangle at TR containing two columns of writing in white
markings: writing and red seal at CL; writing and seal in black ink at BR
portfolio: From Tokaido Gojusan Tsui, Fifty-three pairs of the Tokaido Road
text:
A beautiful woman dressed as a courtesan and accompanied by a young attendant encounters an old monk in this print. The woman dons a pale blue kimono decorated with the King of Hell Enma seated at a desk with a large opened book before him and blue demons stirring cauldrons below. Her garment signals that she is Hell Courtesan (Jigoku Dayū), a 15th-century courtesan who attained enlightenment with the help of the monk Ikkyū. The text in the cartouche at the top left combines two legends associated with Ikkyū: that Ikkyū wrapped his loincloth around a statue of Jizō, a bodhisattva; and that he was respected by the Hell Courtesan.

This print was part of a series titled Fifty-Three Pairs of the Tōkaidō Road, a play on the “53 Stations of the Tōkaidō,” which referred to the highway system that connected Edo and Kyoto. This series was a collaborative venture involving print artists Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861), Hiroshige (1797-1858), and Kunisada (1786-1865). Each print highlights a legend or play that took place at the named station.
title: Station 48: Seki from the series Fifty-three Pairs of the Tokaido Road
